instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No keyboard output
threads.message: [COLOR=#333333][FONT=Verdana][SIZE=13px]So this board was liquid damaged although I saw no signs of liquid damage on the board itself, i cleaned it anyways. The machine boots up and chimes just fine, has all main power rails ect. The only issue is the board isn't recognizing any keyboard input from the internal keyboard. I have tried a new internal keyboard as well as a new trackpad together and neither have made a difference. Also an external keyboard does seem to work perfectly fine its only the internal one. Ideas on anything that could cause this? The machine DOES react to an SMC reset but wont alt-boot when I try to boot from a bootable or get to the boot menu. Also, The caps lock light on the keyboard does not turn on at all when pressed. 3.3v on all caps near the USB controller. <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> is 1 kohms and <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> has 1.3v which seems to be pretty normal. Not really sure where to go from here. Any tips?[/SIZE][/FONT][/COLOR]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No keyboard output
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> should have 3.4V unless power button is pressed! What is voltage on pin 2 <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR>? Both sides should be 3.4V.
Does the trackpad at least work? Then we can at least know <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is working somewhat.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No keyboard output
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 1776"]<CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> should have 3.4V unless power button is pressed! What is voltage on pin 2 <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR>? Both sides should be 3.4V.
Does the trackpad at least work? Then we can at least know <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is working somewhat. [/QUOTE]
<CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> is reading 3.4 now... I might have measured it right as i plugged it in last time so i could have got an inaccurate reading, my bad.. Also <RESISTOR>R5710</RESISTOR> has 3.4v on both pins and the trackpad does indeed work. No lag and the fan spins normally which leads me to believe it was good however I tried a new one anyways just to make sure. I also have tested more than 1 keyboard to rule out the possibility of a bad part

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No keyboard output
threads.message: <CAPACITOR>C5710</CAPACITOR> should be 3.42v almost all the time but this is not the main issue. What voltage is present on pin 30 of the keyboard connector? Does it see the trackpad? Is there any corrosion in the <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> area?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No keyboard output
threads.message: fucking shit duke is fast man. i have to work on my typing. if you can turn it on and off with the button than we ignore <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> section altogether. I think pin 30 of the keyboard connector is corroded.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No keyboard output
threads.message: If trackpad works than <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> is most likely ok. I would first suspect crap in or under KBD connector. Also check all connector pins make contact to <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>.
